bestBHT.bht: The people regarded Jesus as the Prince of Peace in his triumphal entry, fulfilling the prophecy in Zechariah 9:9. Jesus's meekness forbids fear, so the daughter of Zion is told to fear not, even in the midst of difficult times.

Henry Alford: 15.] The prophecy is more fully cited by St. Matthew.
Archibald T. Robertson: Daughter of Zion (θυγατηρ Σιων) [...] The quotation is from Zechariah 9:9 shortened.
So the people here regarded Jesus as the Prince of Peace in the triumphal entry.
When John wrote (end of the century), Jerusalem had fallen. Jesus will lament over Jerusalem (Luke 19:41). So 'Fear not' (μη φοβου).
John Gill: Fear not, daughter of Zion,.... But rejoice; see Zechariah 9:9 and Zechariah 9:9- :.
John Wesley: Fear not — For his meekness forbids fear, as well as the end of his coming. Zechariah 9:9.

bhtAttempts.bht: The people regarded Jesus as the Prince of Peace in his triumphal entry, fulfilling the prophecy in Zechariah 9:9. Jesus's meekness forbids fear, so the daughter of Zion is told to fear not. However, at the time John wrote his Gospel, Jerusalem had fallen, and Jesus would later lament over it. The reminder to fear not serves as a comforting message to the daughter of Zion, even in the midst of difficult times.

The people regarded Jesus as the Prince of Peace in his triumphal entry, fulfilling the prophecy in Zechariah 9:9. Jesus's meekness forbids fear, so the daughter of Zion is told to fear not, even in the midst of difficult times.

The people regarded Jesus as the Prince of Peace in his triumphal entry, fulfilling the prophecy in Zechariah 9:9. Jesus's meekness forbids fear, as he tells the daughter of Zion to fear not. In later times, Jerusalem had fallen, and Jesus would lament over it. The reassurance to fear not serves as a comforting message to the daughter of Zion, reminding her to have faith even in the face of adversity.
